bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, September 19, 1940

div1.p: Hench urges Moran to attend the two college events. Hench discusses the Camp Lazear site.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, September 19, 1940
div1.p: I have just received your letter of September 16.

First of all, I sincerely hope you have changed your mind, and that you
are coming, not only to Washington and Jefferson, but also to Charlottesville,
Virginia. When you wrote, doubtless you did not know that Dr. Hutchison had
finally been able to see Mr. Pew. I have just had a letter from Dr. Hutchison
who said that “the Sun Oil Company would be delighted to pay the expense to bring
Mr. Moran up here.” Regardless of whether Mr. Pew had come across or not, I know
that funds would have been available to have you come, and I see no reason why
you should hesitate to use them. Of course, it is nicer to have the company realize
the good will value of sending you. I have no doubt that what Dr. Hutchison told
Mr. Pew could have done nothing but raise you in his esteem. I know the college is
also paying the expenses of Mr. Kissinger, so please do come:

I hope you will at once re-write Dr. Jordan at the University of Virginia
and will accept their invitation. When I was there visiting my brother this Spring,
I know they were anxious indeed to have you come. Undoubtedly, your time will be
mostly monopolised by Dean Jordan, Mr. Clemons, and members of the medical faculty,
but I do hope you will take enough time out to get to meet my brother somehow, and
at least have a little chat with him. I have written him that you are coming.

Your letter says that your dinner at the University of Virginia was to be
on the twenty-fifth. General Kean had written me that it was to be the twenty-fourth.
I know that they want you in Washington, Pennsylvania, by the evening of the twenty-
fifth, as “Yellow Jack” is being given that night, and I am sure that the college boys
who are putting on this play, will get a great kick out of having you in the audience
with Mr. Kissinger. Don't you suppose you could arrange to have the dinner at Char-
lottesville on the twenty-third or twenty-fourth? I think you can leave Charlottesville
perhaps after the dinner, late at night, and get to Pittsburgh the next morning.
Washington, Pennsylvania is about thirty-five miles from Pittsburgh, and if you arrive,
let us say, by noon on Friday the twenty-fifth, I wil2 meet you and Mrs. Moran in
Pittsburgh, and you can go up to Washington with us, either by car or by train. The
main celebration is on Saturday, the twenty-sixth, but I do hope you can get there by
Friday afternoon, the twenty-fifth. I am sending a copy of this, with a letter, to
Dean Jordan, hoping perhaps to save time and in order that he may know when you have
to be in Washington, Pennsylvania.

Thank you so much for your additional information. I will be expecting
much more soon. I appreciate your kindness in trying to warn me ahead of time that much
of our labor may be lost and that the Cubans will never memorialize the true site of
Camp Lazear, but frankly, I never expected that they would. If we can got them to
memorialize the site they have already picked and do it honestly, that is all that
I can expect. But this has been an interesting research problem for me, and, regardless
Mr. John Moran
- 2 -
September 19, 1940
of what the Cubans do, I want to publish our investigations in a suitable medical
historical journal, and call the matter to the attention of the authorities at
Johns Hopkins, at Washington, at the University of Virginia and elsewhere, and
perhaps accept Miss Cabrera's suggestion to let her friend, the Havana newspaper
man, see the material for possible publication in the Havanapapers. In this way,
at loast, the truth will be known for future historians.
div1.closer: Always sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
